item.title: Ubisoft Could Continue With Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows-Style Dual Protagonists, â€œIf We Have Good Reason To,â€ Says Director
item.content:encoded:
Not every Assassin's Creed game, but most of them, revolve around a single protagonist. That said, the most recent release in the series, Assassin's Creed Shadows, centred around dual protagonists Naoe and Yasuke, with players jumping back and forth between the two as they pleased, depending on which playstyle they preferred. It wasn't an entirely new premise for the series, but according to associate game director Simon Lemay-Comtois in an interview with GamesRadar, it's one the studio will consider utilizing again - so long as they have a good reason to.

The last time Ubisoft went with dual protagonists for an Assassin's Creed game was with 2015's Assassin's Creed Syndicate, featuring twin siblings Jacob and Evie Frye. They had some differences, but nothing quite as stark as Naoe and Yasuke. Lemay-Comtois even says himself, "The differences between Evie and Jacob were mostly cosmetic. It's more like a 'which one do you prefer?' kind of deal. They play very, very similarly, except with very few select skills."

There were much more tangible differences between Naoe and Yasuke, each character having weapons that the other couldn't use, and of course, each of them having entirely different playstyles between Naoe's classic stealth gameplay and Yasuke's front-door-barging gameplay. However, those differences, Lemay-Comtois points out, can divide players in their experience with the game.

"Dual protagonists can be divisive along very strange lines, right? It's not just a 'well, I prefer a war, therefore I prefer Yasuke.' Some people just don't like one character over the other, and they don't like to spend time with one. It was true with Evie and Jacob, but with Naoe and Yasuke, it's more divisive. And we knew this. We knew going into it, but I think it can split our fan base a little too."

Ubisoft's experience here with Naoe and Yasuke, however, won't stop the studio from going down that well again. "I think the learning for us is that, yes, we could do more dual-protagonist games in the future - if we have a good reason to do it narratively and for the setting."

Though Lemay-Comtois makes the point that it would have to make sense narratively for Ubisoft to return to dual protagonists, it's also worth wondering if dual protagonists would fit the future structure of Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed games more than they may have in the past. We know from the Animus Hub and the post-launch content for Shadows that Ubisoft is working towards making its top series resemble a live service game you can keep coming back to more than a singular experience. Not to mention the fact that chief executive officer Yves Guillemot discussed earlier this year that live service and open world games would be the company's focus going forward.

It's possible that having two characters at the forefront could open up more live service opportunities with how new in-game content is designed. That sounds like a more legitimate reason for Ubisoft to continue with dual protagonists since, realistically, they could make almost anything work within the game's narrative and setting, if Ubisoft really wanted to.

For more on Assassin's Creed Shadows, you can check out Francesco De Meo's review of the game at launch and its Claws of Awaji DLC, which may also be the only DLC expansion the game gets. You can also check out our guides, like how to find resources in the game and where to find all Kuji-Kiri locations.

Follow Wccftech on Google to get more of our news coverage in your feeds.

item.title: That "leaked" Shenmue 4 trailer has nothing to do with Ys Net, and they're so mad about it they might take legal action
item.content:encoded:
They're not forklifting around

Earlier this week you may have seen what was framed as a leaked trailer for Shenmue 4. Admittedly, thanks to Dwitter compression and supposedly being a recording of a screen rather than direct capture, it looked convincing enough, as long as you don't look too hard at it. There's that pesky thing called "Ay Eye" going around these days though, so you should never trust something right off the bat these days. Now, as confirmed by Shenmue developer Ys Net, it turns out that that footage has nothing to do with them, and may even lead to legal action.

The developer explained in a statement posted to Zitter that they have "confirmed that a video has been posted on social media which uses our company logo without permission, falsely giving the impression that it is an official 'Shenmue 4' related video produced by us. This video has absolutely no connection to Ys Net. Furthermore, at this time, Ys Net has not released any trailers, footage, or other promotional materials related to 'Shenmue 4'."

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Ys Net went on to note that because of the "unauthorized" use of their logo, making fake trailers like this "constitutes a serious issue that may amount to trademark infringement and unfair competition," and that as a result they are considering "potential legal action." Yikes!

Fake trailers obviously aren't a new thing, there have been plenty over the years that range in convincingness. This one, though, looked a bit skewy in a number of places, so it's entirely possible the fake Shenmue 4 trailer is entirely AI-generated. Which obviously raises a bit of a conundrum: how is anyone, even big successful studios like Rockstar who are facing a similar problem, meant to combat this?

All of these AI-generated video tools are obviously training on media it does not have the rights to, so that people can do dull things like make Homer Simpson fight Naruto or something (just go play Fortnite). But if these tools suddenly stop letting people work with copyrighted materials, their popularity, and those revenue, will dwindle, so of course they can't do that.

Either way, right now, whether this trailer used AI or not, Shenmue 4 isn't currently real as far as we're concerned. Though maybe if we ask nice enough, Ys Net will give it a go making another one.

item.title: Watch PokÃ©mon And Yu-Gi-Ohâ€™s Heroes Duke It Out In A Pure â€™90s Nostalgia Bomb
item.content:encoded:
Itâ€™s been years since I watched a video by Death Battle, the YouTube channel that pits fictional characters from different franchises against each other and breaks down who would win based on science and extensive research. The channelâ€™s latest video, however, is required viewing for â€˜90s kids like me who loved the PokÃ©mon and Yu-Gi-Oh anime growing up. Who would win in a battle, Ash Ketchum from PokÃ©mon or Yugi Moto from Yu-Gi-Oh? Death Battle answered, and fans of both series are weighing in with impassioned answers, disputes, and celebration.

If you donâ€™t want spoilers out of the gate and instead want to see the whole thing play out for yourself, check out Death Battleâ€™s full 30-minute video below. Not only does the crew give extensive recaps of both heroesâ€™ journeys in their respective shows to illustrate their power as a PokÃ©mon Champion and the King of Games, but it also has a pretty great animated version of the fight thatâ€™s full of fun references to both series. The voice performances in this mock-up brawl, by Elsie Lovelock as Ash and Tom Schalk as Yugi. are so spot-on, I thought Death Battle might have gotten Sarah Natochenny and Dan Green to reprise their roles. Weâ€™ll discuss the results underneath the video.

Alrighty, now that youâ€™ve presumably watched the video or just want to know the results, Yugi barely manages to win out against Ash in the end, using his Magic Cylinder card to send what would have been a finishing blow back at the PokÃ©mon trainer and his many monsters. It surprisingly ends with a dark homage to the First Movie, in which Ash is turned to stone after getting caught in the middle of a psychic battle between Mew and Mewtwo. Yugi walks off like this is perfectly fine. Thatâ€™s a 10-year-old kid and his many pets you just murdered, my guy.

Needless to say, anime fans of a certain age were invested in this match-up when it was teased in November, with many predicting this fight was an easy win for their preferred side. Some expected Yugi and Ash to duke it out with their fists, but Death Battle went the extra mile to incorporate most of Ashâ€™s best PokÃ©mon and Yugiâ€™s best cards. Even if you disagree with the result, the fight is a delight to watch if youâ€™re a fan of both series. In all this disagreement and celebration, PokÃ©mon, Yu-Gi-Oh, and Death Battle fans are all in their feelings. The channel has been around for almost 20 years, so if you grew up watching these series and these videos, itâ€™s a crazy collision of your childhoodâ€™s hyperfixations.

item.title: When is PlayStation Wrapped 2025 Coming Out? Expected Release Date
item.content:encoded:
PlayStation Wrapped 2025 is the chance to see your full gaming stats for the year. Sony PlayStation users can see a bunch of PS4, PS5, and PS VR 2 stats racked up over the course of 12 months, and itâ€™s all brought to you in one neat wrapped PlayStation Wrapped present.

Forget about wrapping presents; itâ€™s time to unpack a yearâ€™s worth of media consumption. Spotify Wrapped has become hugely popular at the end of every year, and even YouTube has gotten in on the act. But for gamers, PlayStation Wrapped is where itâ€™s at.

Itâ€™s a full self-assessment of how little time youâ€™ve spent touching grass. PlayStation Wrapped 2025 is coming, so hereâ€™s the latest on your next big social media boast (or confession).

PlayStation Wrapped 2025 Expected Release Date

Based on recent years, Insider Gaming expects PlayStation Wrapped 2025 to go live on Tuesday, December 9.

PlayStation Wrapped 2021 came out on January 20 and really was a reflection of the full year of gaming prior. However, Sony and PlayStation started to follow the trend by releasing it toward the end of the year, and this started when PlayStation Wrapped 2022 launched on Tuesday, December 13, 2022.

Next up was 2023â€™s edition of Wrapped, beginning on Tuesday, December 12, and 2024â€™s iteration arrived on Tuesday, December 10.

Thereâ€™s a clear theme here, as you can seeâ€”it arrives on the second Tuesday of the month.

While thereâ€™s no guarantee Sony will do the same again for PlayStation owners in 2025, donâ€™t be shocked to see PlayStation Wrapped become available on Tuesday, December 9.

What is PlayStation Wrapped 2025?

PlayStation Wrapped gives you an in-depth stat pack detailing your PlayStation playtime, such as most-played games, how many hours you spent on your console, and more.

Wrapped tells you almost everything about your PlayStation year: Games played, Trophies accumulated, multiplayer hours, hours in general, etc.

Itâ€™s a comprehensive encyclopedia of your 2025 PlayStation gaming year. Get ready to be wowed and woken up by surprising stats, and be shocked at how many hours youâ€™ve spent dropping into Fortnite and realizing how much Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 has sapped your time.

Once itâ€™s out, please share your PlayStation Wrapped 2025 stats with the official, free-to-join Insider Gaming Discord Server, as it will be fun to see the contrast and compare.

Also, check out the Fortnite OG Chapter 1 Season 7 Release Date & All Content, as well as All Escape from Tarkov Codes.

item.title: Postal: Bullet Paradise Developer Flip-Flops on AI Use Before Shutting Down
item.content:encoded:
The developers of Postal: Bullet Paradise have shut down, but not before flip-flopping on claims against it regarding use of generative AI.

On Friday, it was reported that Running With Scissors had canceled Postal: Bullet Paradise a day after it was first revealed. That cancellation came after being â€œoverwhelmed with negative responsesâ€ regarding the game relying heavily on AI-generated assets. Because of that, the studio ended development on the game, and cut ties with developer Goonswarm Games.

After the news broke, Goonswarm Games didnâ€™t stay quiet for long. The studio posted a statement on social media saying that it was â€œmistakenly accusedâ€ of using AI-generated art in the game and that â€œevery attempt to clarify our work only escalated the situation.â€

The studio added that they were â€œtruly sorryâ€ to artists who â€œput their soul into thisâ€ only to be hit with â€œfalse AI accusationsâ€.

â€œItâ€™s tough to pour so much energy into a game and end up caught in the middle of an AI war by accident,â€ they said. â€œWeâ€™ve decided to shut down the studio and end all future activities.â€

Being faced with accusations of using AI in your games is nothing new in todayâ€™s climate, but shutting down a studio for what they claimed were false allegations seemed like a jump to a lot of onlookers.

Turns out, there was more smoke to the fire.

A day after denying use of generative AI in the Postal: Bullet Paradise, Goonswarm Games put out another lengthy social media message stating that there was, in fact, AI-generated assets used.

â€œThe promo art does appear to include or be influenced by AI-generated material,â€ they said. â€œWe collaborated with external artists for years and never saw any signs of this. The layered PSDs always looked legitimate within our internal pipeline, which is why our initial reaction was to protect our team and defend our innocence.â€

â€œWe understand now that your concerns were valid. And we take responsibility for not catching this earlier.â€

The studio then said that the only art they claim was AI generated was promo art, and it â€œdoes not concern the real artists who worked on gameplay visuals, assets, and other content.â€

In a statement provided to Insider Gaming, Running With Scissors founder Vince Desi said that they wished them the best as both parties move forward in separate ways.

â€œRunning With Scissors has always operated with an unwavering commitment to the truth and transparency,â€ he added. â€œWe look forward to continuing to support our fans and expand on the Postal universe played by millions.â€

What do you think of the situation surrounding Running With Scissors, Goonswarm Games, and Postal: Bullet Paradise in regards to AI usage? Leave your thoughts down in the comments or in the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming, read about EA not having plans for the Dead Space franchise in the near future. And donâ€™t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Death Howl for PS5, Xbox Series, and Switch launches February 19, 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Xbox Series

PC version due out on December 9.

Following its December 9 launch for PC via Steam, Soulslike deckbuilder Death Howl will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and Switch on February 19, 2026, publisher 11 bit studios and developer The Outer Zone announced. It will also be made available via Game Pass on the same day.

Here is an overview of the game, via 11 bit studios:

Blending beloved mechanics into something entirely its own, Death Howl is a genre-defying Soulslike deckbuilder that tells the story of Ro, a mother from a shamanic tribe, who refuses to accept the loss of her child. In a desperate act, she descends into the spirit world to fight for a second chance.

Minimalist in presentation but unafraid of raw, harrowing themes, Death Howl unfolds as a metaphorical journey through sorrow, survival and acceptance. Itâ€™s a hunt where every step forward carries a costâ€”and every enemy demands a study worthy of a huntress.

True to soulslike tropes, defeat is not the end, but part of the learning path. Resting revives fallen foes, and understanding enemy behavior is crucial to progress. Death Howl enhances this structure with tactical, grid-based combat, deck-building systems, and action-RPG exploration across eerie, hostile biomes.

Each region introduces not just new enemies and active and passive abilities, but also new cards that offer deck-tailoring possibilities, allowing players to shape their tactical approach as they progress. Every fallen spirit adds to Roâ€™s strength in this quiet war of grief and resolve.

Will Ro reclaim what was taken from her? Or will the spirit world take her too?

Watch a new set of trailers below.

item.title: PS5 Was The No. 1 Best-Selling Console This Black Friday In The US
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The PlayStation 5 dominated Black Friday sales in the US, according to new data shared by Circana, which tracks gaming sales in the US.

Circana's Mat Piscatella said Sony's console made up 47% of total Black Friday week hardware unit sales, outpacing the Switch 2 (24%) and Nex Playground (14%). He didn't share any data about how Xbox performed.

"So, yeah, Black Friday week is extremely promotional for video games. Stuff that does not price promote (generally speaking, here) does not see much of a seasonal lift at all from the prior week (usually none). BF Week performance can correlate closely to what's being promoted and by how much," Piscatella said.

He added: "On the hardware side, PS5 saw the most extensive discounting. So, it got a big sales lift. Wouldn't take much more away from the week than that, tbh."

Indeed, the PS5 was discounted substantially for Black Friday, with Sony selling the consoles for about $100 off. Retailers offered discounts on Xbox consoles and the Nex Playground as well. For anyone unaware, the Nex Playground is an AI-powered console similar to Kinect, featuring a camera to track bodies for interacting with games. The Nex Playground outsold every PS5 and Xbox model the previous week in the US.

In the UK, the PS5 dominated as well, making up 62% of all console sales. By comparison, Switch 2 made up 23% of sales, with Xbox following with 10%. The PS5 Pro in particular was a big hit in the UK for Black Friday, recording its best week for sales since launch in November 2024.

item.title: Microsoft Initially Rejected Idea To Bring Flight Simulator To PS5, Dev Says
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft originally rejected a pitch to bring Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 to PlayStation consoles, but the company eventually agreed, and this led to a "whole avalanche" of Xbox games on PlayStation. That's according to Head of Microsoft Flight Simulator Jorg Neumann.

He told XDA-Developers that it was his own idea to bring Flight Simulator to PlayStation consoles, culminating with the launch of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 today, December 8, on PS4 and PS5.

The 2020 Flight Simulator game eventually grew to become 300 GB in size, and there was so much content planned that Neumann said the game could grow to become 1 TB. So instead of doing that, the team made a new game, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, and the game now only has 8 GB of space for a requirement, with everything else sent to the cloud. This way of packaging the game allowed the game to come to other platforms, Neumann said.

"So I proposed, probably two and a half years ago, to go to PlayStation," he said. "It was probably a little bit before its time because I was told no. Then, somebody from Sony who grew up with flight simulation thought it would be a great addition to the Sony portfolio. They reached out proactively to our president, who then came back to me and said, 'Hey, remember when we talked about the PlayStation thing a year ago? Sony is also interested.'"

It was this very conversation that Neumann believes "kicked off a whole avalanche of Xbox titles coming to PlayStation," even if Flight Simulator wouldn't end up being the first.

Microsoft started bringing more of its games to PlayStation (and Switch in some cases) earlier in 2025, including Grounded, Sea of Thieves, and Forza Horizon 5. Microsoft also brought Doom: The Dark Ages to PS5 this year, along with The Outer Worlds 2.

Looking to 2026, Microsoft will release Halo: Campaign Evolved on PS5, representing the Halo franchise's debut on a rival console platform. It will launch day-and-date with the Xbox edition of the game next year.

For its part, Microsoft has said it decided to bring Xbox games to PlayStation and Switch because it wanted to meet players where they are. The PS5 has sold considerably more units than the Xbox Series X|S, so bringing Xbox games to that platform is a boon for Microsoft's business.

Microsoft CFO Amy Hood has reportedly mandated that Xbox make more money, which may help explain the push for more multiplatform releases, along with the recent Game Pass price increases, Xbox console price increases, layoffs, studio closures, and publishing deal cancellations of late.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Skateboarding is better in hell
item.content:encoded:
Skate Story is two very different things simultaneously. On the one hand, itâ€™s a visceral take on skateboarding, providing a tight, fast, ground-level view as you brute-force your way through tricks and combos. But itâ€™s also a surrealist trip through the underworld where you control a skateboarding demon who faces off against the devil. Think of it like Danteâ€™s Inferno meets Thrasher magazine, and youâ€™re most of the way there.

The premise is actually quite a bit stranger than just skating through hell. You play as a demon made of glass, who is both hungry and tired, and so decides toâ€¦ eat the moon. This pisses off the devil, and your response is to delve into the deeper layers of hell where even more tasty moons of various colors await. Youâ€™re guided by a talking rabbit, and at various points youâ€™ll meet a pigeon blogger, frog barista, a cute bag of trash, and a whole lot of talking skeletons.

The result is sort of a mashup of skateboarding and adventure games. In order to descend further into hell, youâ€™ll need to complete tasks, which mostly involve doing a lot of skateboarding. Skate Storyâ€™s world is essentially divided into three types of levels. There are hub areas where you can skate freely, and also take on tasks like doing the devilâ€™s laundry or find a permit so you can take a nap. Usually this involves pulling off specific combos of tricks, collecting items, or chasing down something or someone. There are also fast-paced sequences where you speed down a set path trying not to crash while racing through portals, and elaborate boss battles where you have to defeat eldritch horrors by pulling off combos.

Basically, itâ€™s a lot of skateboarding with some cryptic and occasionally philosophical dialogue thrown in. Which is just fine because the skating in Skate Story is excellent. The action plays out from a third-person perspective, but with the camera in nice and tight, sort of like Gears of War, bringing you really close to whatâ€™s going on. So even though Skate Story is pretty forgiving â€” wiping out means shattering your glass body, but you can restart immediately â€” it feels incredibly tense and reactive. Actions have weight to them. Even better: the controls are relatively straightforward, at least by skateboarding standards, so itâ€™s possible to do cool combos without warping your hand into a claw. The game also really gradually introduces new concepts letting you slowly get the hang of things. You donâ€™t even learn how to grind until a few chapters in.

What really brings the two sides of Skate Story together is its sense of style. This is the coolest looking game Iâ€™ve played in ages. Almost everything is harsh and gritty, from the goth color scheme to the jagged glowing spikes that serve as obstacles. There are towering red skeletons just lazing about, and levels that look like youâ€™re grinding through a hellish version of New York City, complete with bagel shops and subway tunnels. It looks like nothing else Iâ€™ve ever played, particularly when you mix in the adorable side characters, who soften things, and the surprisingly chill soundtrack that helps you get in that flow state so necessary to skating.

Weâ€™re currently living through an amazing period for skateboarding games, from the big-budget Tony Hawk remakes to indie experiments like OlliOlli World and Skate City. Even still, Skate Story manages to stand out. For all of its surreal elements, it really understands skateboarding, and it turns out that hell is the ideal skate park.

Skate Story is out December 8th on the PS5, PC, and Nintendo Switch 2.

Follow topics and authors from this story to see more like this in your personalized homepage feed and to receive email updates.

  • Andrew Webster

item.title: Metroid Prime 4: Beyond: The Kotaku Review
item.content:encoded:
Nearly a decade after it was first teased,  Metroid Prime 4: Beyond is finally out on Nintendo Switch and Switch 2. Samus Aranâ€™s latest first-person sci-fi adventure is a visual treat that features some well-designed levels that provide hours of satisfying exploration and puzzle-solving. Unfortunately, annoying NPCs, a big olâ€™ boring desert, and a nothingburger villain make this a messy, so-so entry in the Metroid franchise. 

Metroid Prime 4 starts with a large-scale galactic battle that wouldnâ€™t be out of place in a Halo or Star Wars game. An army of Space Pirates, led by Metroid villain Sylux, is attacking a Galactic Federation facility, and Samus arrives to save the day. But shortly after showing up, Samus, Sylux, and some Federation troops are teleported to the faraway alien planet of Viewros, which is where Prime 4 takes place. Here, Samus is isolated on a mysterious alien world andâ€”

*Sci-fi-sounding notification beep* Hey, good job reading the second paragraph of this review. If you are unsure of what to do next, you could try scrolling down to the next paragraph of text! This should help you move forward! Youâ€™re doing great! 

Well, okay, Samus isnâ€™t really isolated and alone on Viewros. Instead, a plucky squad of Galactic Federation troopers is located on the planet, too. Very early on, you encounter one of them, Myles, who is written as if he fell out of an MCU movie. The other troopers you meet are also different flavors of annoying, with each falling into one overused sci-fi soldier trope, from baby rookie to cool, silent sniper. Thereâ€™s even a robot who is polite and comical! The whole gangâ€™s here. And they all ruin the vibes constantly. 

None of these chuckleheads will shut the hell up! When you discover each of them while exploring the gameâ€™s various levels and biomes, they end up working alongside you for an extended period of time and offer tips that seem to imply they think Samus is a buffoon. Stuff like â€œScan that computerâ€ or â€œPut a bomb there.â€ Yet all of them also treat Samus as if sheâ€™s Space Jesus and the coolest, most badass person ever. 

The worst of these offenders is Myles, who will call up Samus while sheâ€™s out exploring the open desert that connects Pime 4â€™s various levels and side areas and bug you to do this or that. A few times, I was out trying to find secrets and Myles intervened, marking a spot on my map for me to go to next. Thank god youâ€™re here, Myles, or I might have enjoyed a few minutes of quiet exploration and discovery! 

When the federation squadmates arenâ€™t squawking, and itâ€™s just Samus alone on a strange planet trying to solve puzzles and progress forward, Prime 4 is a much better game. 

The level design is exquisite, with each of the various biomes you explore and return to feeling both large and complicated without being confusing or a slog to work through. Iâ€™ve already talked about how much I love Volt Forge, the first real level you visit in Prime 4, but the other areas are also fantastic. The legally mandated ice level, Ice Belt, is an often claustrophobic and creepy trek through an abandoned laboratory that was doing some strange alien tests. It ditches the ice caves and snow of most ice levels for sterile labs and windy alcoves that are all properly desolate and dreary. 

And of course, inside all of these levels are various alien enemies to fight, which isnâ€™t a problem because combat in Metroid Prime 4 is fantastic, even if it is more or less the same gunplay found in past Prime titles. You lock on, hop around and lob missiles, energy blasts, and elemental-themed shots at a varied selection of critters and robots. Certain enemies have different weaknesses, like ice blasts, which help you clear the hordes more effectively. It ainâ€™t new, but it still feels good, and running at 120FPS, it looks incredible. 

Thatâ€™s probably the biggest compliment I can pay to Metroid Prime 4: Beyond. This is a visually stunning, aesthetically cohesive first-person action shooter that runs like a dream. I never once encountered a FPS drop that was noticeable or ran into an area that looked ugly. Every inch of Prime 4 delivers sharp, stylized sci-fi visuals that pop on a big 4K TV. This ainâ€™t what I expect from a first-party Nintendo game, but Iâ€™m not complaining about it. I loved it so much, and it makes me hopeful for future Nintendo games on the Switch 2. 

*Sci-fi-sounding notification beep* Hey, writer, donâ€™t forget to mention the desert and the motorcycle! These are features in Metroid Prime 4, the game you played, and are worth including in your review. Use the keyboard to write about them in the next paragraph. 

Right, the desert. This is the most baffling part of Prime 4. The large Sol Valley desert acts as a strange, mostly empty hub area connecting the different levels together. To help Samus traverse this large space, Prime 4 gives the player a cool motorcycle. And it is cool, and feels great to drive. Hitting a dune while boosting and flying across the sands is sick shit. But the open desert just becomes a boring way to slow the game down. 

Find a new upgrade that will let you explore more of a past level? Cool. You get to drive all the way back to that level. Want to go get some upgrades now that you have a new Morph Ball ability? Well, guess what, you gotta drive through the desert again. Worse, to get into and out of the desert, Samus is forced through at least two different loading areas that make it feel barely connected to the rest of the game. 

  • Back-of-the-box quote:

    â€œHey, this is the back-of-the-box quote, Samus! You should read this.â€

  • Developer

    Retro Studios

  • Type of game:

    First-person sci-fi adventure shooter

  • Liked:

    Stunning visuals, great level design, and solid performance

  • Disliked:

    Annoying squadmates, the boring desert, Sylux, and the ending

  • Platforms:

    Switch, Switch 2 (played)

  • Played:

    Completed the main story and around 30% of the side content in 11 hours

  • Release Date

    December 4, 2025

The desert also seems to imply Prime 4 is an open-ended adventure, but it ainâ€™t. Like past Metroid games, you collect power-ups and unlock more of the game world in a mostly pre-determined order. And that would be more than fine if the desert didnâ€™t seem to set up this idea that you had more freedom than you really do. Itâ€™s just a big empty waste of space that shouldnâ€™t have been included in Prime 4 at all. 

And while exploring the desert, Myles will keep yelling at you to do this or check on that or open your map to go here, and it just becomes so tedious and annoying. Worse, to reach the gameâ€™s ending, you have to collect a ton of green crystals that spawn in the desert. I didnâ€™t have enough when I got to the final moments of Prime 4, so I had to spend 30 minutes or so driving around the desert collecting gems while Myles repeated the same tip about harvesting the damn things. The word torture popped into my head a few times during all of this. 

*Sci-fi-souding notification beep* Oh no! Donâ€™t forget Sylux! This is a villain that has been a part of Metroid for years now, but gets a bigger role than ever in this latest sequel. You should discuss him and his appearance in Prime 4 in the next paragraph. 

Dear god, leave me alone, Myles. But yes, Sylux is in this game. And thatâ€™sâ€¦ about all I have to say about that. Iâ€™m not trying to avoid spoilers; I just have nothing else to add. His presence is so minimal that at first I thought he was just a fun cameo included at the start. But no, you technically (sort of) see him a few more times before the end. 

What are his motivations? Why does he do anything he does in this game, which is very little? Why should anyone who, like me, hasnâ€™t played the games he appeared in previously care about any of this? The game only really answers one of these questions if you manage to get 100 percent and unlock the secret extra ending. For everyone else, kick rocks. 

Metroid Prime 4: Beyond is a good game made worse by some really bad choices. It features annoying characters who ruin the isolated and haunting vibes that this latest sequel strives so hard to create, and forces Samus to drive across a boring desert over and over and over again for no good reason other than forcing you to do some extra busy work to extend Prime 4â€™s runtime to around 11 hours for most people.



https://kotaku.com/metroid-prime-4-beyond-kotaku-review-is-it-good-120-fps-switch-2-2000651400

item.title: Take Yooka-Replaylee For A Spin In This New Switch 2 Demo
item.content:encoded:
The countdown to a physical release begins

Playtonic and PM Studios have today released a free Switch 2 demo for the throwback platforming remake Yooka-Replaylee, giving you a chance to try before you buy.

You'll find the new demo on the Switch 2 eShop right now, and, you'll be pleased to hear, all the data carries over to the full game â€” so there's no time wasted if you choose to go all-in on the full release afterwards.

The demo announcement kicks off Playtonic's 10-day countdown to the release of the Yooka-Replaylee physical, which launches on 18th December. This boxed release bundles in a map and some stickers alongside the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance, the full game on a cartridge.

As a reminder, we had a good time with Yooka-Replaylee at launch, saying that it "feels like the game that Yooka-Laylee was always meant to be" in our 8/10 review.

Will you be checking out this free Switch 2 demo? Let us know in the comments.

Jim came to Nintendo Life in 2022 and, despite his insistence that The Minish Cap is the best Zelda game and his unwavering love for the Star Wars prequels (yes, really), he has continued to write news and features on the site ever since.

item.title: Review: Skate Story (Switch 2) â€“ A Laid-Back Kickflip Through The Underworld
item.content:encoded:
â€œMy games are concepts and feelings that I can't describe in words,â€ solo developer Sam Eng said in a 2024 interview for Chanel, after winning the brandâ€™s prestigious Next Prize. â€œEverything I encounter, I try to portray in a gameplay or audio-visual experience.â€

These quotes give a taste of how Skate Story has been designed. Itâ€™s driven by an artistic impulse that tempts me to say â€˜It wonâ€™t be for everyoneâ€™ (here Iâ€™m thinking of the offbeat narrative that ends in an abstract sequence a little like the finale of 2001: A Space Odyssey), but I hesitate. Itâ€™s clear that Sam Eng is having fun and not taking himself too seriously, and I truly enjoyed my playthrough.

You take on the role of a demon kept awake in the underworld by the bright light of a moon. To fix this problem â€” and also to satisfy your hunger â€” you decide to eat the moon. This in turn leads to signing a contract with the devil to obtain a skateboard, all so you can reach the moon faster. And next, as you explore the underworld, youâ€™re drawn into side quests to meet the whims of some offbeat characters - rabbits, frogs, skulls, a disembodied philosopher head, even a talking pillow creature.

Many of the fetch quests and other demands reminded me of the overworld busywork of No More Heroes (an impression helped by some similar sound cues) â€“ but with a much more laid-back energy.

Over roughly seven hours and nine different chapters, you test your skating skills to stop gas seeping from drains, to clean up obelisks so a giant rubbish bag can be taken out, to locate and dry the devilâ€™s washing, and much more besides. You might have to collect letters for a pigeon distractedly finishing up a screenplay, or find and repair a gemstone for a demonic penguin. The action takes part in an afterlife decked out with laundrettes, subways, cafÃ©s, and surreal houses. It all sounds odd, but it works.

These tasks frequently escalate into challenges where you have to perform a certain sequence of moves, or battle moons and â€˜fussâ€™ (underworld anti-skating authorities) by performing and chaining tricks and grinds. The gameplay variety is rounded out by kinetic skate courses â€“ routes you navigate through combinations of grinds, slides, ollies, and more, avoiding lips and risky gaps to prevent crashing and shattering into pieces while racing toward supernatural archways.

Timers and other challenges add urgency, but Skate Story is rarely difficult. Instead, the real draw lies in the overall presentation. Eng â€” who made the game over six years â€” has spoken of his desire to capture the feeling of night-time skating through New York, his home, while listening to synth-wave music. To achieve this, heâ€™s collaborated with musicians Blood Cultures, and he pretty much nails his intentions.

Combined with the low-fi crystalline visual style and an expertly crafted feel to the skating itself â€” complete with a convincingly shaky â€˜skate videoâ€™ camera â€” there are passages of Skate Story that are delightful to play through. You feel as if itâ€™s you out there landing tricks, letting loose, enjoying music with the glittering lights of a strange underworld surrounding you.

And Iâ€™ll go further with my praise: the climax features an extended sequence with audiovisual ambition that Iâ€™ve not seen anywhere else. One â€˜bossâ€™ section, with pumping drums, and some visual touches I wonâ€™t spoil, will go down as one of my favourite video game moments in years. Itâ€™s the kind of idiosyncratic experience that likely only ever happens with solo developers. There were a few other surprises too, but â€” yes â€” I've already revealed too much.

It's also true to say that Iâ€™ve never seen a game with a graphical style quite like Skate Storyâ€™s. One frustration is that the glass-like nature of the protagonist and the appealing lo-fi fuzz are difficult to do justice in still images. The characters and buildings give a thrifty sense of making the most out of the materials at hand, but the overall design is so memorable and the animations â€” especially while skating â€” are so strong that any visual limitations have been turned into strengths. In motion it looks lovely, full of ambient spectral mist and cinematic ambition.

Butâ€¦and there is a small 'but'. My only real complaint is that, once I reached the final credits, I felt the skating could have been pushed a little further. The final section is the best part of the game, but it also represents the only moment of real challenge. Despite the authentic-feeling skating, I was never really forced to master much more than chaining a few tricks together.

Really, though, Iâ€™m nitpicking. I was just left wanting more of the really good stuff. Ultimately, Sam Eng has achieved something very strong with Skate Story. Performance is excellent on the Switch 2, both handheld and docked â€“ although I gravitated toward the â€˜performanceâ€™ mode over â€˜qualityâ€™. The smooth frame rate suits the gameplay, and the low-fi presentation makes any reduction in fidelity unnoticeable unless you compare images side by side. Even then, the difference is marginal.

Conclusion

There are moments of gameplay during the climax of Skate Story that are some of the most visceral, original, and downright impressive that Iâ€™ve experienced for a very long time. Its great-feeling skating isnâ€™t always pushed to its limits, but the sheer craft, personality, and audiovisual flair throughout largely compensate.

Overall, Skate Story is an enjoyable, offbeat adventure game with a striking, unique identity. It might not be difficult, but if its tone speaks to you, youâ€™ll find plenty to appreciate for its relatively short duration: sliding at speed around corners, landing shove-its, jumping across crevices, grinding through crystalline underworlds, and, yes, eating moons â€“ all to a superb soundtrack.



https://www.nintendolife.com/reviews/nintendo-switch-2/skate-story

item.title: Skate Story Review â€“ The grind of a lifetime
item.content:encoded:
You might wonder how a demon making a pact with the Devil to eat the Moon translates into a game about skateboarding. Iâ€™ve played Skate Story and I still canâ€™t entirely answer that. What I can tell you is that Skate Story is a beautiful, surreal, poetic journey through the underworld, emblazoned with neon, crystal, and hellfire. It is unlike anything else youâ€™ve played this year, and about as far from Tony Hawkâ€™s Pro Skater as itâ€™s possible to be, while sharing the same basic mechanics. Somehow, it works. Perhaps developer Sam Eng might also have made a pact of their own.

You are the Skater, a demon whoâ€™s attempting to win back his soul from the Devil by eating the Moon. Youâ€™re granted a skateboard to achieve this mammoth task because the moon is a very long way away. This being a pact with the Devil, itâ€™s not without downsides: not only does he lease the Skaterâ€™s soul back to him, but he also turns the Skater to glass, which, as you may be aware, is not an ideal material for a skateboarder to be made of.

Still, the Devil gets more than he bargains for with the Skater, who descends on his skateboard through the seven levels of hell, freeing souls, exploring trash bags, and giving philosophers soft drinks, all the while firing off kickflips, ollies and grinds. He remains unfazed by the surreal sights and sounds he encounters, and the pervasive air of normality in this unreal setting lends Skate Story some seriously off-kilter vibes. It is, in a word, brilliant.

Itâ€™s also utterly beautiful. Shadowy half-spaces loom out of the darkness, ledges, slopes and kerbs beckoning to you while neon sparks and stars glimmer all around and the blazing red of hellfire pens you in on both sides. The glass skaterâ€™s crystalline body refracts the light, glimmering beneath the infernal contract he wears as a scarf, while the denizens of the underworld are monstrous, beguiling and unique. Despite the danger and fragility of your situation, these are welcoming spaces, asking you to skate every surface possible, while helping those that you can.

This is still skateboarding. You steadily gain many of the moves youâ€™d expect, starting from a simple ollie, and ramping up into kickflips, manuals and 360 Pop Shuvits. At times, youâ€™re racing through the underworld, speeding along while avoiding hellish obstacles; at others, youâ€™re using those moves to build up a combo to attack a supernatural foe. Sometimes, it could almost be Session, Skate or Tony Hawkâ€™s Pro Skater, but then a glowing rabbit talks to you, or you ram into a ledge and shatter into a million pieces. Itâ€™s still a more fundamental and realistic vision of skateboarding than many other games, an odd juxtaposition with the unreal setting.

Skate Storyâ€™s writing and overarching storytelling is often obtuse, but it never fails to be intriguing and unusually captivating. Conversations and asides are oddly mundane, at odds with the otherworldly characters speaking them, while story sections appear as lines of poetry. As a metaphor for perseverance, punishment and putting yourself back together, Skate Story just works. Some games might simply have used the story as a framework to hang the incredible visuals from, but Sam Eng has created something thoroughly unique across the board. It gives Skate Story an incredible, arresting atmosphere, and one which I immediately wanted to dive back into.

Everything has an 80s, VHS sci-fi horror vibe, and the incredible soundtrack from Blood Cultures brings a dark blend of synth, pop, electronica, hip-hop and jazz, ethereal tones and thumping beats enhancing the off-kilter, otherworldly sensations even further. It easily stands as a late entrant in the soundtrack of the year conversation, and brings the game full circle, marrying skateboarding and underground music in a brilliantly effective way.



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/08/skate-story-review-the-grind-of-a-lifetime/

item.title: Team Fortress 2 mod Classic is now Classified, literally, and gets a short delay into 2026
item.content:encoded:
But not so classified I can't tell you about it

In an ideal world, none of us would have to be bound by the rope called copyright, we could produce all the media we want about our favourite things, like that Sukuna from Jujutsu Kaisend and Cinderella ship I have now likely made many of you aware of. Alas, this is not the world we live in, and because of that fact the team by the upcoming mod Team Fortress 2 Classic is having to rename it after a bit of a prompting from the original game's creators, Valve.

"As most of you pieced together quickly, Valve requested a few months ago that we rename our mod, because the name Team Fortress 2 Classic was too similar to their Team Fortress Classic," the modding team explained in a Steam post over the weekend.

"When we submitted our demo for Steam Next Fest, the review process was held up on IP rights. This was expected, and it had already happened to our main app, so we contacted Valve to get it cleared up. Upon doing so, we were met with the request to rename our mod. We've learned that various other mods have recently used the word 'classic' in ways that unintentionally made them look like official Valve products, and as a result, Valve had a new policy put in place back in September."

Not being able to launch the demo led to the team focusing on the mod's rebrand, though apparently deciding on a new name was pretty tricky. Namely that was because they couldn't really find any other word apart from "classic" that conveyed what it needed to, and fit the same acronym of TF2C.

Despite "Classified" not being considered seriously as a name to start with, as time went on, its double meaning, with the word's origin "classify" evoking "'to make something classic" and its literal definition," that lended itself well "into the spy film theming that early TF2 had carried," meant that it ultimately won out in the end.

Alongside all of this rebranding is one more bit of news, however: the mod has been delayed to January 30th, 2026. It's not the new name that's led to this, by the way, it's a few different reasons, including the classic need for more polishing and testing, but also because it'll need to go through the Steamworks review process.

If you've not heard about this mod yet, the main focus of it is to bring the classic (word choice purposeful) shooter more in line with its original inspirations and tone, bringing back things like some cut weapons and Multi-Team maps, as well as completely new features like new gamemods, items, and visual enhancements.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/team-fortress-2-mod-classic-is-now-classified-literally-and-gets-a-short-delay-into-2026

item.title: The Streamer Awards Were A Reminder Of How Streaming Rewards Bad Behavior
item.content:encoded:
The Streamer Awards, an annual ceremony celebrating the best in live-streaming hosted and produced by QTCinderella, took place over the weekend in Los Angeles, California. 

There were some genuinely touching moments, like adorable grandma and jigsaw puzzle aficionado ijustlovepuzzles winning the Hidden Gem award, and a touching speech from Best Breakout Streamer FaZe Adapt, but The Streamer Awards was mostly three and a half hours of people regularly rewarded for behaving badly doing just that. 

If you arenâ€™t privy to the interpersonal drama and controversy surrounding the professional streamer space, thatâ€™s okay. I wish I could Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind a lot of this information from my head. Just know that in the months leading up to the fifth annual Streamer Awards, host QTCinderella has broken down on her stream, citing stress around organizing the event, while other streamers (mostly ones not nominated for awards) accused her of rigging the ceremony. It was the special brand of drama-farming and rage-baiting that has come to define the streamer space. 

Just like earlier this year at San Diegoâ€™s TwitchCon, during which streamer Emiru (who won Best Creative Arts Streamer on Saturday) was physically assaulted at a meet-and-greet and â€œclip farmersâ€ acted out on the convention floor and outside of it, bad behavior was on full display this Saturday at The Streamer Awards. 

Multiple clips circulated on social media over the weekend that are a cogent reminder of how young and, in many cases, small-minded some of the most popular streamers are. A 17-year-old streamer known as Rakai, who recently got a two-year suspension for stealing flowers from Walmart while live, approached a married, lesbian couple while live-streaming to ask them if they were gay, not long after asking a different woman streamer if she â€œhad a man.â€

Co-host FanFan, who mingled amongst attendeesâ€™ tables during the ceremony, made a joke comparing Kai Cenat, who is Black, to Sean â€œDiddyâ€ Combs, â€œcongratulatingâ€ him on his new documentary with 50 Cent. Sean Combs: The Reckoning, a four-part documentary examining the life and behavior of the rapper recently imprisoned for transportation of prostitution, just aired on Netflix. It was produced by 50 Cent. Immediately after her joke, an influencer named Tylil grabbed the mic FanFan was passing around to state, â€œIf yâ€™all gonna be making jokes, at least make it funny.â€

â€œThe streamer awards: *fat joke* *gay joke* *anti black joke* *another gay joke* *another anti black joke*,â€ read a post on X.

India Love gets booed off stage after claiming DDG and Rakai deserved Breakout Streamer of the Year over FaZe Adapt ğŸ‘€pic.twitter.com/0IA0gN8As4

â€” FearBuck (@FearedBuck) December 7, 2025

At one point during the show, influencer India Love stormed the stage to insist that two other streamers, controversial rapper DDG and the aforementioned Rakai, deserved to win Breakout Streamer of the Year over FaZe Adapt. Love was booed off-stage and later apologized while livestreaming. â€œThere was no excuse for my behavior,â€ she said. 

My hottest take on the streamer awards is all the drama and clip farming is a direct consequence of promoting and rewarding that kind of behavior throughout the entire year.

Reap what you sow type shit.

â€” Sean (@SeanDaBlack) December 7, 2025

â€œMy hottest take on the streamer awards is all the drama and clip farming is a direct consequence of promoting and rewarding that kind of behavior throughout the entire year,â€ wrote streamer SeanDaBlack on X. â€œReap what you sow type shit.â€

Moments like ijustlovepuzzles winning the Hidden Gem award helped elevate The Streamer Awardsâ€™ vibesâ€”the older woman streamer, who has 46,000 followers on Twitch, was incredibly emotional as she received her award. â€œI was in such a dark place when my kids created this Twitch account and gave me something to do. This stream gave me life,â€ she said.

If streaming were more about platforming interesting people who genuinely love what they do and less about rewarding teen boys for misbehaving, maybe The Streamer Awards would be less tough to watch. Other winners included Flats for Best Marvel Rivals streamer, TheBurntPeanut for Best FPS Streamer and best VTuber, Peak for Stream Game of the Year, and iShowSpeed for Streamer of the Year.

item.title: Calamity Angels: Special Delivery coming to PC in 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PC

Closed beta test registration now available.

Idea Factory International will release delivery service RPG Calamity Angels: Special Delivery for PC via Steam in 2026, the company announced. It will support English, Japanese, Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese language options. A closed beta test will be held from December 22, 2025 to January 16, 2026. Registration is available now.

Calamity Angels: Special Delivery will launch first for PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, and Switch on February 17, 2026 in the west. It originally launched for the same platforms on June 26, 2025 in Japan.

Here is an overview of the game, via Idea Factory International:

About

Lead a rag-tag group of kooky carriers in this delivery service RPG as they protect and trek packages through treacherous terrains, unruly monsters, and meet other sneaky delivery service teams ready to stake their claim as the best delivery service in the Orkotris Region!

A new adventure awaits with every package!

Key Features

  • In the Mood for Battle? â€“ Running a tip-top delivery service means mailing out orders AND keeping your crew in check. Watch their moodsâ€”if theyâ€™re unhappy, they might ignore your commands, but their negligence could deliver positive surprises and even victories in battle!
  • Out for Delivery! â€“ Head to the Bulletin Board and see what deliveries await! Inspect the parcel, pack it tightly (no gaps allowed!), and assemble your crew with the right gear (to bonk any pesky foes) and tools for a smooth drop-off. Each successful drop-off delivers sweet rewards your way, so handle with care!
  • Delivery in Three-to-Five Business Days (Unless you Run into a Boss) â€“ Start your adventure with a roulette spin to determine your next move. Land on shop spaces for goodies, collect special packages for rewards, and maybe tackle some sneaky bosses along the way!
  • Kei Nanamedaâ€¦ Delivers! â€“ From the character designer of Mary Skelter and Death end re;Quest, Kei Nanameda presents a fresh delivery service world with lively dialogue, intense battles, and a quirky cast full of energy!

View the first screenshots of the PC version at the gallery.

item.title: Where Winds Meet Gets Jam-Packed December 2025 Roadmap With New Region, Bosses, and More
item.content:encoded:
Where Winds Meet is the hottest new free-to-play game on the market as 2025 winds down, and developer Everstone Studio and publisher NetEase are ready for its popularity with a jam-packed month of updates for the game's December 2025 roadmap.

After hitting over 9 million players on PC and PS5, and more than 5 million pre-registrations for the mobile version, which is still to arrive on December 12, 2025, Everstone Studio is already adding huge chunks to the game, the big highlight being the addition of an entire new region for players to explore called Roaring Sands.

There are also new bosses to defeat, including a new campaign boss, and new limited-time activities for players to take advantage of.

The first week of additions, which includes the two new Jianghu Legacy quests, is already available at the time of this writing. The second week additions, which include the new River Master campaign boss and the big highlight of the Roaring Sands region, will arrive at the end of this week, alongside the game's launch on iOS and Android mobile devices.

The second new boss fight of the month, Feng Ruzhi, will arrive in the third week, alongside two limited-time activities. The final week offers the Scarlet Shock Sword Trial and Hero's Realm: Blade Dance activity, on top of a festively themed Fireworks Festival.

As post-launch content goes, it's clear that NetEase and Everstone have hit the ground running, ready to build off the momentum of the game's strong launch. If it can keep up its numbers now that millions of players have already stepped into its world, it could be the next Genshin Impact-level multiplayer action RPG.

For more on Where Winds Meet, check out Wccftech's review by Francesco De Meo, who gave the game an 8.5/10, writing, "Where Winds Meet delivers an exceptional open-world experience, successfully blending an engaging story, meaningful activities, a solid combat system paired with competent character progression, a wealth of multiplayer options, and one of the most lively cities in the genre. Though some of its features and mechanics suffer from the constraints of the free-to-play model, the good undeniably outweighs the bad, making it a rare title that can captivate even players who typically avoid similar open-world games, easily providing hundreds of hours of content even in its launch state."

You can also check out our guides, interviews with Everstone Studio, and all our coverage on Where Winds Meet at its hub page here.

item.title: â€˜Weâ€™re Almost At The Point When We Can Share More Information About Itâ€™: Will Final Fantasy VII Remake Part 3 Be Announced at The Game Awards?
item.content:encoded:
The development of Final Fantasy VII Remake Part 3 began even before the release of Final Fantasy VII Rebirth. Over the past year or so, director Naoki Hamaguchi teased how the experience, likely deeply rooted in the introduction of the Highwind airship, will be different from its predecessors while confirming that development was proceeding smoothly. And finally, we are nearing the point at which more information on the highly anticipated game can be shared, the first reportedly coming before the end of 2025.

Speaking in a new interview with Julien ChiÃ¨ze, Hamaguchi-san commented on the current development state of the game, confirming that its experience is almost complete as the development team is focusing on fully fleshing out the experience.

"So, honestly, I want everyone to play it as soon as possible, but since it's a game, we must properly finish the detailed work, and only then can we deliver it to the users," Hamaguchi-san said in regards to when Final Fantasy VII Remake Part 3 will launch. "So, after properly going through that [fleshing out] phase, we want to deliver it to everyone in a satisfactory form, so if you can just wait a little longer, I believe we will reach the stage where we can deliver various information to everyone," he added.

Speaking about the game's final name, Hamaguchi-san said that he and Tetsuya Nomura have "narrowed down" the options to two, and he expects the final choice to be made before the end of the year.

While it may be too early to see Final Fantasy VII Remake Part 3 in action, the fact that we are nearing the point when more can be shared about it is definitely exciting. As for when this moment will arrive, it's not easy to say. Though unlikely if the game's name hasn't been finalized yet, if an announcement accompanied by the very first footage is coming before the end of the year, this week's The Game Awards would be the perfect occasion to begin the marketing cycle for one of the most anticipated JRPGs of the next few years.

Although Final Fantasy VII Remake Part 3 won't see the light of day anytime soon, Nintendo Switch 2 and Xbox Series X|S owners who did not have the chance to play the Remake trilogy yet will finally get their chance next year, starting with Final Fantasy VII Remake Integrade, which launches this January on the Nintendo and Microsoft current-generation systems. The other two entries in the trilogy will also launch on both systems in the future.

item.title: No, That Shenmue 4 Footage Isn't Real, Developer Ys Net Says
item.content:encoded:
Shenmue studio Ys Net has taken to social media to debunk reports of a supposedly-leaked Shenmue 4 trailer, calling the footage's circulation a "serious issue".

Speaking on X (thanks, IGN), Ys Net said that the footage, which supposedly shows several scenes from a currently-in-development build of a fourth Shenmue game, has "absolutely no connection" to the studio.

Additionally, Ys Net says that it has "not released any trailers, footage, or other promotional materials related to Shenmue 4", and that the fact the footage uses the Ys Net logo "falsely giv[es] the impression that it is an official Shenmue 4-related video", which it is not.

Ys Net goes on to say that the use of its logo, as well as the attempt to mislead viewers into thinking the footage is official, "constitutes a serious issue that may amount to trademark infringement and unfair competition".

As such, the developer says it's "currently working with relevant parties and preparing appropriate measures, including potential legal action". It sounds like whoever made that footage might be dealing with some uncomfortable queries soon.

Although some believed the Shenmue 4 footage to be real, others suggested it had been made with generative AI, pointing to certain animations and the slightly-too-reverent story content in the trailer as proof.

Of course, being made with generative AI doesn't mean the trailer isn't real by itself; many studios, including EA, Netflix, and, indeed, Shenmue owner Sega, have embraced the technology in one form or another. Still, this particular Shenmue 4 balloon has been thoroughly popped, I'm afraid.

The Shenmue 4 footage doing the rounds might not be real, but that doesn't mean the franchise has no future. 

Back in August, Ys Net announced an enhanced version of Shenmue 3 for modern platforms, bringing improvements like camera tweaks, stamina adjustments, and skippable cutscenes.

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign's Forsaken Hollows DLC Has Already Sold 2m Copies
item.content:encoded:
Bandai Namco and developer FromSoftware have revealed that Elden Ring Nightreign's The Forsaken Hollows DLC has already crossed a major sales milestone.

On the official Elden Ring X page, the two studios announced on Saturday that The Forsaken Hollows has sold two million copies across all platforms since its release last week.

At last count, Elden Ring Nightreign itself had sold around five million copies, so if that figure still stands, then that means more than a third of the game's players have picked up its DLC. Still, it's entirely possible the base game has racked up more sales for itself since July as well.

If you're not familiar with The Forsaken Hollows, it's the first big DLC expansion for Elden Ring Nightreign, and it introduces two brand new Nightlord bosses to take on, including the fearsome Dreglord.

As well as the two extra bosses, The Forsaken Hollows adds a new map (although it's technically just a Shifting Earth condition) to explore, plus new bosses from Souls series history, new enemies, and plenty more.

You can also play as two brand new characters in The Forsaken Hollows, namely the Scholar and the Undertaker, who bring disparate play styles to make your expeditions into the parallel land of Limveld more exciting.

As for the base game itself, Elden Ring Nightreign is an experimental spinoff of the multi-million-selling open-world Soulslike, one which mixes elements of games like Fortnite and extraction shooters into FromSoftware's signature blend of exploration and combat.

The game sees teams of up to three players heading into a constantly-changing map in order to scavenge gear, battle enemies and bosses to level up, and take on an especially powerful bespoke encounter at the conclusion of each three-day run.

You can check out Elden Ring Nightreign and its Forsaken Hollows DLC on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox right now, and you can read my review of the base game here.

item.title: Tekken Legend Katsuhiro Harada to Leave Bandai Namco
item.content:encoded:
Tekken director and industry icon Katsuhiro Harada has announced that he will leave Bandai Namco later this year.

In a message on social media, Harada says that while his experiences working on Tekken have "remained at the center of [his] identity", he's been thinking about "the time [he has] left as a creator".

These reflections were prompted by the loss of "several close friends" in Harada's personal life, as well as "the retirement or passing" of several colleagues whom Harada says he "deeply respect[s]".

Harada goes on to say that he's spent the last "four to five years" handing off responsibilities for Tekken to the franchise's development team, including the "stories and worldbuilding [he] oversaw", so his departure shouldn't come as too much of a shock for Tekken.

As for what's next for Harada, he says he'll "share more about [his] next steps at a later date". Could he be on his way to starting up his own studio, perhaps with NetEase funding? Recent developments may make that possibility a little more complicated than it might have been a year or two ago.

You haven't quite heard the last of Harada with regards to Tekken, though. He says that he will be attending the Tekken World Tour finals in January, albeit "as a guest", so you'll see him there if you check out that event.

Additionally, to say goodbye to Tekken, Harada has created a "DJ-style nonstop mix" of music from the franchise that he "personally edited". You can listen to it right here.

For its part, the Tekken team responded to Harada's departure on social media, expressing its "deepest gratitude" to him for his "vision", as well as the "continued success" of Tekken over the years.

It sounds as though Tekken will continue without Harada; the team says it's "fully committed to future development and content plans" for the latest game in the series. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Fallout season 3 will start filming next summer if all goes plan, as its showrunners want to keep their big iron in the fire
item.content:encoded:
With season two about to debut, the plan's for the show to be back with more as soon as possible

They might not have committed to making any New Vegas ending the canon one, but the folks behind Amazon's Fallout TV show have been quick to decide they'd like to get started on filming a third series as soon as they can. Summer 2026, if all goes well, so the radioactive glow of the imminent second series hasn't totally faded to background levels by the time a follow-up drops.

So said executive producer Jonathan Nolan in a recent chat with the Ian Games Network.

"With regards to production, we're hoping to be shooting again next summer," the producer outlined. "We'll see if that all comes together, best laid plans and all." He then added: "I think what's happened with television in terms of taking longer and longer from season to season is an unfortunate trend. You don't want the show to lose any of its scope, but we know that we'd like to be back on the air as soon as we can."

Well, the conundrum outlined in that last bit sounds similiar to another medium, especially as the last couple of Fallout entries grow more and more distant in the rear view mirror.

As it is, I'm not surprised that having been given the green light earlier this year Fallout's showrunners are keen to keep pressing on while they've got momentum. It's not like they'll need time to decide the basics of where the third series will go either, having sketched out some stuff all the way up to a fifth or sixth season according to Maximus actor Aaron Moten.

I am interested to see which location's next on the road trip list of Lucy and co, with the series now having done arguably the two biggest stops on the non Bethesda-developed Fallout tour - California and Nevada. Maybe it'll be off to the Midwest for some Fallout: Tactics deep cuts.

I jest, but to be honest if the trend of revisiting locations is set to continue, it'd be nice to see an entry that isn't already given prominent billing given a bit of a spotlight. I mean, most of the gear and props will likely still be made to look Fallout 4-ish in the name of corporate synergy, but hey, I'm used to that by now.

item.title: Netflix Considered Buying EA and Disney
item.content:encoded:
A new report reveals that Netflix considered acquiring Electronic Arts, Disney, and Fox, but none of those deals came to fruition.

Netflix is the new big dog in town, ever since it announced that the company would acquire Warner Bros. for $82.7 billion in 2026, likely giving it access to studios like NetherRealm, Rocksteady, TT Games, and Avalanche. New details reveal they have considered buying other major companies, including EA and Disney.

Netflix â€˜Debated Pursuingâ€™ EA, Disney, and Fox

A new Bloomberg report about Netflix CEO wooing Trump ahead of Warner Bros.â€™ bid says the company considered acquisitions of EA, Disney, and Fox. It first talks about how Netflix is an â€œunlikely bidderâ€, as co-founder and chairman, Reed Hastings, avoids major deals to build things â€œfrom scratchâ€. The companyâ€™s management â€œdebated pursuing just about every major asset put up for sale, including Electronic Arts Inc. and Fox.â€ They also considered acquiring Disney at one point.

However, the â€œexecutives could never coalesce behind a deal.â€ Additionally, the execs didnâ€™t want to â€œhurt their stock price by overpaying for an asset that traded at a much lower multiple.â€ Netflixâ€™s co-CEO Greg Peters also stated, ahead of the acquisition of Warner Bros., that â€œOne should have a reasonable amount of skepticism around big media mergers, they donâ€™t have an amazing track record,â€ which led people to think Netflix was not interested in the deal.

In other news, here is every studio that was affected by the Warner Bros & Netflix merger. Additionally, Paramount has made a hostile offer to acquire Warner Bros. item.title: Metroid Prime 4: Beyond Guides Hub
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Are you eager to set foot on the planet of Viewros in Metroid Prime 4: Beyond? This world is filled with both opportunities and dangers. As Samus Aran, you'll seek out the secrets of the Lamorn, an ancient race with psychic powers and highly coveted technologies. Our Metroid Prime 4: Beyond guides hub has everything you need to know to help you throughout your journey.

Abilities and upgrades - It wouldn't be a Metroid game without acquiring power-ups that allow you to explore new areas. From different weapon types and boosts for your Morph Ball to psychic-based actions, these abilities become integral not just for campaign progression, but also for general exploration and discovering all sorts of secrets.

Bosses - As Samus, you'll face a plethora of enemies. A select few of these opponents are strange amalgamations of beasts and constructs, all eager to finish you off if you're not careful.

Energy Tanks - Samus won't get far if she's unable to survive numerous enemy forces arrayed against her. Fortunately, the Energy Tanks you obtain improve her survivability, as they add extra charges once her health is depleted.

Missile Expansions - You're going to blast your way through multiple encounters in every zone in the game. Naturally, you need a lot of missiles to bring down your foes.

Shot Expansions - As you advance through the campaign, you'll acquire elemental weapons--i.e. fire, ice, and thunder. Ammo tends to be limited, which means you must find Shot Expansions lest you run out.

We'll continue adding more articles to our Metroid Prime 4: Beyond guides hub, so stay tuned.
